Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the significance of the finds in the Canal Saint-Martin by describing them as "frightening," when in reality they were regular trash.
Understate: There is no evidence of any understatement bias in the claim.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it fails to provide accurate information about the regularity of the canal's draining and the nature of the finds.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the draining of the canal for the first time in 200 years led to "frightening finds," which is not supported by the evidence.
Exist alternative explanation: There is no alternative explanation bias present in the claim.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the Canal Saint-Martin is drained approximately every 15 years, not every 200 years.
Falters at times: The claim falters by presenting misleading information and misrepresenting the rarity and nature of the canal draining and the finds.
